stories.text:
I am in the current session of Hack Reactor. Galvanize has basically removed all Hack Reactor branding from the instructional content. Hack Reactor no longer offers any in-person courses or an SF campus.[1] There appear to be about 30 students in the course, in the entire Western US (not just CA). They literally can't fill sessions. The internal Slack is completely dead.

Worst of all, the material so far hasn't been updated in at least 10 years, judging by the dates on the latest commits. We're learning early 2000's Doug Crockford-style JS. I wonder if the rest of the course material is like this, too.

The course still costs ~$20K.

Is Hack Reactor basically dead? Are there any Bay Area bootcamps that are a better deal and offer industry networking or employer contacts?

[1] https://www.hackreactor.com/blog/shift-to-remote-software-engineering-education
stories.title: Ask HN: Has Galvanize completely gutted the Hack Reactor brand?

stories.text:
Is there such a notion of minimum exhaustive application or a benchmark application that really tests what it's like to develop in a "stack" or programming language? One that is complex enough to cover real-world problems at scale.

In the ML world we have the notion of a benchmark dataset which we use to evaluate the performance of an ML model. (This approach has its own flaws.. models can potentially overfit on the benchmark data set)

After that you would need some criteria to evaluate the stack or programming language under consideration.

One response is to say "there are too many potential things to test, this is not possible" or you could go the other direction and say "pick your favorite CRUD app". But wondering if these things have been thought out in a way that there is some type of happy medium.
stories.title: Ask HN: Minimum testable application to evaluate a stack?
